title: How do you rebuild self-discipline from scratch?
opening_message: "I've been struggling to get my motivation back on track since I started feeling better from depression, and I'm worried that it's holding me back from fully recovering."

all: I've let my self-discipline slip away due to depression and feeling overwhelmed by tasks.
Trying (and failing) to get things done was making my depressive symptoms worse.
Now that I'm getting better, my lack of self-motivation and inability to complete tasks is hindering my recovery.
I'm trying to get assessed for ADHD because I think it might be contributing to my struggles with motivation.
It's tough for me to get an assessment done where I am, so I need alternative solutions in the meantime.
I feel stuck between wanting to make progress but being unable to muster the energy and motivation to do so.
The fear of not knowing what's holding me back (ADHD or something else) is frustrating and disempowering.
I'm worried that my lack of self-motivation will hold me back from achieving my goals and moving forward in life.

turns.content: "I've been struggling to get my motivation back on track since I started feeling better from depression, and I'm worried that it's holding me back from fully recovering."

"Ah, you're noticing a connection between your progress and your motivation. It can be tough to maintain momentum after working so hard to overcome depression. Can you tell me more about what 'getting my motivation back on track' means to you? What are some things that used to get you excited or driven, but now feel lacking?"

"I guess what's frustrating me is that I used to be really driven by a sense of accomplishment, you know? I'd set goals for myself and crush them, feeling like I was making progress and moving forward. But now it feels like no matter how hard I try, nothing seems to get done. It's like I'm stuck in this perpetual state of 'not good enough', where everything I do is just half-hearted and unfulfilling. And it's really discouraging me from putting in the effort required to keep improving."

"It sounds like you're missing that sense of accomplishment and fulfillment, which was a big motivator for you before. It can be really tough to feel stuck and uncertain about your progress. Have you tried setting smaller, more manageable goals for yourself lately? Maybe ones that aren't as lofty or overwhelming, but still allow you to build some momentum and celebrate small wins?"

"I guess I just feel like I've been trying to push through, forcing myself to tackle big projects and goals, but it's all feeling like too much right now. Even setting smaller goals feels daunting because I know I won't be able to stick with them. It's like my motivation has just disappeared, and I don't know how to get it back."

"It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed by the pressure to perform and achieve big things again. It's like your motivation is MIA right now. Can you tell me what self-care looks like for you during this time? Are there any small, gentle practices or habits that bring you comfort and calmness?"

" Honestly, doc, I've been so caught up in trying to figure out what's going on that I haven't really prioritized self-care. I mean, when you're feeling stuck and unmotivated, it's hard to muster up the energy for stuff like meditation or journaling. Lately, though, I have found myself scrolling through social media a lot more than usual, almost as if I'm trying to escape from my own thoughts."

"It sounds like you're using social media as a coping mechanism, and that's understandable when you're feeling stuck. It can be a way to temporarily distract yourself from your thoughts and emotions. But are there any specific things or accounts that you find yourself scrolling through repeatedly? Is it the FOMO (fear of missing out) aspect, or is there something else drawing you in?"

" Yeah, I think it's a mix of both FOMO and just trying to escape from everything. When I'm scrolling through Instagram, I find myself getting sucked into these highlight reels of other people's lives, thinking 'oh, they're having more fun than me' or 'I should be doing that too'. It's like, I know it's curated, but still...it feels like there's this constant pressure to keep up. And honestly, it's hard for me to stop when I'm feeling stuck and overwhelmed - it just feels like a way to temporarily numb everything."

"It sounds like you're caught in the cycle of comparing yourself to others and feeling like you're not measuring up. That can be really tough to break free from. Have you tried setting some boundaries for yourself around social media use? Like, are there specific times of day when you allow yourself to scroll, or certain accounts that you've blocked or muted?"

"I don't know, man... I guess I just feel like no matter how hard I try, I'm always coming up short. Social media doesn't help - it's like everyone else is living this perfect life and I'm just stuck in neutral. Setting boundaries sounds like a good idea, but honestly, I'm not even sure where to start."

"It sounds like you're feeling really discouraged and struggling to see any hope or progress. It can be tough to feel like everything is going wrong and that you're stuck in one place. Can you tell me about something - anything - that you used to enjoy doing, but haven't done in a while? Maybe it's a hobby, a game, or even just taking a walk outside?"

"I don't know, man... I used to love playing guitar, but it feels like a lifetime ago since I've picked one up. It's weird, 'cause sometimes I'll catch myself thinking about it or looking at old music sheets, but then I just get overwhelmed and shut down. I feel like there's something holding me back, but I don't know what it is... and that not knowing is just driving me nuts."

"It sounds like playing guitar holds a special place in your heart, even if you haven't picked one up in a while. The fact that you're still thinking about it and looking at old music sheets suggests there's a part of you that's wanting to revisit that part of yourself. What do you think is the biggest obstacle that's keeping you from picking up a guitar again? Is it fear, lack of time, or something else entirely?"

"I think it's a mix of things, but if I'm being honest with myself, I'm really afraid that I've lost my sense of purpose and drive. Playing guitar used to give me this rush of excitement and fulfillment, and I think that's what I'm missing now. But whenever I try to get back into it, I feel like I'm just going through the motions, you know? Like I'm doing it out of obligation rather than passion. It's like my motivation is stuck in neutral, and that's really frustrating for me."

"It sounds like you're struggling with a sense of purpose and drive, and that playing guitar was a source of fulfillment for you in the past. The fear of not being able to recapture that feeling can be really tough to overcome. What do you think would happen if you were to take small steps towards getting back into playing guitar? Would it be like trying to force something to happen, or could you imagine finding joy and purpose in the process again?"
